So far as short fun games are concerned, this is the best for me. If I ain't in the mood for a more competitive or difficult game, this is my go to. Games are short, luck + some skill based, and full of vibes. This is not a highly complex, play for 5 hours a day game, this is a short 15 minute poker game after work kinda game.

Buckshot Roulette turns a simple gamble into a tense, fast-paced mind game. Its shotgun mechanic raises the stakes and keeps every decision suspenseful. Players balance luck with strategic item use to influence the outcome. The dark, club-like atmosphere adds constant pressure. Quick rounds make it highly playable without feeling repetitive. Chance plays a major role, but smart choices still matter. Overall, it‚Äôs a small game with sharp design and lasting impact.

This is definitely a vibes game, extremely short and simple. There‚Äôs a bit of strategy involved in how you use the items given, but I was able to beat it in one run (which took about 30 minutes). I suppose you could do the ‚Äúdouble or nothing‚Äù run, but it didn‚Äôt seem there was much incentive unless you just wanted more. All that said, the atmosphere is immaculate, and there‚Äôs really nothing to fault the gameplay. What it does, it does well.

Playing Russian roulette with a creepy guy in a mask who somehow out-gambled GOD for money is a crazy concept that delivered in full. Not only is it very cheap, but it is addictive to see how high you can get with your cash prize before getting shot in the face after taking questionable meds with a few energy drinks on the side. There is also multiplayer which really ups the feeling of trying to play mindgames with people before screwing someone over. It is a very fun game and worth it if you just want to play a game where you have an excuse to shoot someone without playing an FPS.
Incredible concept. Russian roulette meets horror with perfect tension and style ‚Äî short but unforgettable.

Amazingly replayable with an awesome aesthetic and a mysterious yet grim tone to match. Very good at being immersive with its sound design, and the gameplay makes it feel like if you know what you're doing you can negate the game of chance or play it to be absolutely in your favor. The items shake the game up almost every time they pop up, and playing around what the Dealer has is such a fun experience. It's not too difficult to catch on and play for a good while, even if you happen to have memory issues! A great time all around.

negative.review:
https://youtu.be/8aMG2rlRZL4

Whatever hidden secrets may be part of this experience are buried too deep to make up for the RNG based unlock method for whatever may be there.
Kinda pointless if you play solo, it's clearly intended as a multiplayer only game. I don't have friend so no reason to play.

It looks pretty, I'll give it that. The atmosphere is cool, music is good. It's entertaining for about 15 minutes and quickly goes downhill from there.

Despite looking literally like a 1995 game with a 256 color palette, the performance is relatively abysmal, worst optimized Godot game I have ever seen. "Partial controller support" means that your controller might not work as advertised or, in my case, double any input, making it useless.

There's no content, just making coin toss decisions ad nauseam. I cannot believe 6 gorillion people bought this "game" and even compared it to a masterpiece like Inscryption. This has to be in the top 5 overhyped titles of the XXI century. I sincerely believe that to enjoy this game you must either be a fentanyl zombie, a cocomelon lobotomy survivor or a simian whose neurons activate with any dice roll, regardless of context. At this point you should just give in to your programming and simply go gamble in an online casino. At least then you might win something. 

How am I supposed to derive satisfaction from a game that, in order to be won, needs literally only luck and nothing else? 

Fans of this piece of dogsh√≠t will defend it by sharing tips about making regular breaks when angry or fatigued... That the "game" has "roulette" in the name after all! And that the fun is derived from manipulating the odds in your favor. Except that the only way to do that are items, most of which are useful in very specific situations or barely useful at all, depending on - you guessed it - luck. They are also assigned randomly. Enjoy the heights of strategic pondering and amusement when you try to decide who to shoot with a 50/50 chance of live round or dud OR perhaps making a 50/50 coin toss to decide whether pills will regenerate 2 health points or take away your last one. Try to predict what your 3 HP opponent with healing, scrying and damage items will do. 

And if you still want to "play" this then you better have good short term memory AND be prepared to give it your full and undivided attention. The initial shells loaded into the shotgun each round appear only once for about 1.5 seconds. If you had the sheer audacity to look away from the screen for an inopportune moment, you might as well restart the whole run, as you won't be able to gauge the probabilities at all. And there's about 90% chance that your enemy will have perfect memory and will follow predefined optimal decision branches. This is, in actuality, the crux of the game and it's only source of anything you could call "difficulty". That, and weird probability results to your disadvantage that seemed to have sparked achievement ideas. Have "fun" I guess.

But the above shell count thing is just a single smelly piece of undigested corn sticking out of the fecal iceberg of this game's abysmal design and lack of anything resembling QoL. Animations are long, unnecessary and irritating. There's no way to skip them or make them faster. You WILL "enjoy" them to the fullest EVERY TIME. It seems benign at the beginning, but a game like this should run instantly. This is the only way to facilitate players getting into the "zone" of repeating the gameplay loop until they sh√≠t themselves on stream. Instead, you spend about 3% of the game time actually thinking or clicking and 97% of the time just watching the same 5 animations which aren't even that entertaining in the first place. The whole interface is garbage. You can't even back out of using the shotgun or an item if you misclick, which is something that seems absolutely basic, expected, low bar and immediately detectable in any serious testing. But "nooo, this is le edgy game, no hand holding!!! You clicked the shotgun, so either choose the target or reset."

For some bizarre reason the online mode is for 4 players only, so I have no idea how that changes anything about the game, as no 9ne seems to play it online anymore.

This could have been a mildly entertaining VR experience, given some polish, QoL improvements and INSTANT game world feedback, but apparently this is too much to ask. 

I'm absolutely disgusted with this title and disappointed in gaymerz. I'm glad I got this in a bundle, as the ~$2.50 is way too much. Don't even @ me.

1/10 not a fan

Buckshot Roulette is a gritty and dark depiction of a 1-on-1 showdown against a body-less nightmare in Russian Roulette. The twist? You play with a shotgun. The premise is creative, mayhaps even enticing, but the execution? Meh.

The game opens in a bathroom, graffiti'd and ominous. You're sat against a toothy demon of sorts and told to play his game. 30 minutes later, win or lose, credits roll, and you're out. What is this place? Who is this guy? Why am I here? Answer none of these questions and more in Buckshot Roulette!

The gameplay is simple, but satisfying to master. A number of rounds are loaded into the shotgun per round and you're shown how many are lives versus blanks. You must mentally keep track of this number while using items granted each round to eject the round, check the casing, and other effects. By the end of my duel with the Dealer, I felt I had achieved some sort of mastery, but unfortunately, this also spelled the end of the game, and that skill went to waste.

I think this game could've benefited a lot from a little exposition maybe, a few more challengers perhaps, another couple of items and combos to use... I'm told that's basically Inscryption, but this isn't Inscryption. It's Buckshot Roulette, and while it's cool on a conceptual level, it feels unfinished and closer to a stylish demo.

Review as a single player game:
At it's core, this is a puzzle game.  It is a puzzle game with a very grim aesthetic, but it's still just a puzzle game.

It's a very slight experience.  Which for just $3 is fine.  There is only one opponent in single player, and it is well coded to play mostly optimally.

And that's the main problem with the single player experience.  The items and mechanics are completely imbalanced to the randomization.  It is completely possible for the randomizer to give you a situation where even with perfect play it is impossible to win.  When you need to win roughly 15 straight games (for the million point achievements), that creates some VERY frustrating experiences.

This review is a victim of Steam's binary Yes/No review system.  It's an entertaining experience, but horribly broken.  Which is a shame, because with a little more work (better balancing on the items, a couple more opponents, a little more clarity on the scoring) this could have been a premium game.
Doesn't save any progress, not gonna go through all 3 levels again just because I wanted to turn down the super loud music.

Well, this game is neither fun nor well designed.

First off, this is pure luck (beside the stats that you can calculate). OK, to be fair, they added several objects to tamper the luck aspect of the game, but still. While in other roguelikes, the rng is not the sole aspect of the game, in Buckshot Roulette, there is nothing else to play with.

In the making, this game is also a chore: there is no way to pass all these lengthy animations (several seconds), which makes the game extremely slow pace, and thus artificially increasing the game play time, which I really hate.

Honestly, you will have more fun with a dice or two.
had fun for 2 - 3 runs but then it started getting repetitive, 100%ing is mid, just boring, it needs more settings and ai upgrade, for the price its a solid 6/10

I hate to give a negative review to a game I got in a bundle for practically nothing, but I'm honestly very confused as to how this game is rated overwhelmingly positive. 

The art style is okay, but that's the best thing about it, from what I've seen.

About 45 minutes in, and I feel like I've seen most of what this title has to offer. I haven't played all the way through the "Double or Nothing" mode, so possibly there's a lot I'm missing ... but from all appearances, I doubt it.

The core game loop is very simple, heavily RNG-based (not necessarily a bad thing), though there is some strategy available with usable items. In the time I've played, however, it feels pretty shallow.

I don't hate it, but it's pretty lackluster so far. Might give it another try and update this review if my opinion changes.

edit: I went back. I do not particularly enjoy games of chance, but you know what I should be fair - maybe this is just a 'not for me'. I'll check that there is not in fact a hurry the f$&% up mode in the settings. No? OK, maybe you can press a button or something, I can't remember for sure if I did that. I *hate* this game, and it's lack of respect for player's time.

The game is very fun, but it has unfortunately not recieved updates since 2024 and since the Vulkan driver updates, the game just doesn't load properly. You can use a workaround, but it doesn't seem to work for everyone and it's obviously not the way the game was intended to be rendered on screen. This seems to be more of an issue with the game engine than with the game itself, but still, I do not recommend buying this game until it is fixed.
Game has a bug that just prevents you from playing the game as your screen is Permanently black. Cannot recommend the game until this is fixed, which seems unlikely.

Was about to refund this...

Game would boot to the menu and let me select a game mode but when loading into a game I would get only audio with black screen.

Found fix on reddit:

1. Right-click Buckshot Roulette in your Steam Library
2. Select 'Properties...'
3. Paste under 'Launch Options' the following (without quotes):  "--rendering-driver opengl3"
4. Close the window and try launching the game.

OpenGL3 Makes the game look like over-saturated crap but at least I can play it...  Not like this game is much on the visuals anyways and I only spent $1.25 on it so I'll keep it but wanted to post this fix in case anyone else has this issue.

Fun party game with friends for 1/2 nights.

Also the game is surprisingly unstable.

tldr : Worth the price and pretty fun for 3 hours. After that, do not bother.
Kinda pointless if you play solo, it's clearly intended as a multiplayer only game. I don't have friend so no reason to play.

It looks pretty, I'll give it that. The atmosphere is cool, music is good. It's entertaining for about 15 minutes and quickly goes downhill from there.

Despite looking literally like a 1995 game with a 256 color palette, the performance is relatively abysmal, worst optimized Godot game I have ever seen. "Partial controller support" means that your controller might not work as advertised or, in my case, double any input, making it useless.

There's no content, just making coin toss decisions ad nauseam. I cannot believe 6 gorillion people bought this "game" and even compared it to a masterpiece like Inscryption. This has to be in the top 5 overhyped titles of the XXI century. I sincerely believe that to enjoy this game you must either be a fentanyl zombie, a cocomelon lobotomy survivor or a simian whose neurons activate with any dice roll, regardless of context. At this point you should just give in to your programming and simply go gamble in an online casino. At least then you might win something. 

How am I supposed to derive satisfaction from a game that, in order to be won, needs literally only luck and nothing else? 

Fans of this piece of dogsh√≠t will defend it by sharing tips about making regular breaks when angry or fatigued... That the "game" has "roulette" in the name after all! And that the fun is derived from manipulating the odds in your favor. Except that the only way to do that are items, most of which are useful in very specific situations or barely useful at all, depending on - you guessed it - luck. They are also assigned randomly. Enjoy the heights of strategic pondering and amusement when you try to decide who to shoot with a 50/50 chance of live round or dud OR perhaps making a 50/50 coin toss to decide whether pills will regenerate 2 health points or take away your last one. Try to predict what your 3 HP opponent with healing, scrying and damage items will do. 

And if you still want to "play" this then you better have good short term memory AND be prepared to give it your full and undivided attention. The initial shells loaded into the shotgun each round appear only once for about 1.5 seconds. If you had the sheer audacity to look away from the screen for an inopportune moment, you might as well restart the whole run, as you won't be able to gauge the probabilities at all. And there's about 90% chance that your enemy will have perfect memory and will follow predefined optimal decision branches. This is, in actuality, the crux of the game and it's only source of anything you could call "difficulty". That, and weird probability results to your disadvantage that seemed to have sparked achievement ideas. Have "fun" I guess.

But the above shell count thing is just a single smelly piece of undigested corn sticking out of the fecal iceberg of this game's abysmal design and lack of anything resembling QoL. Animations are long, unnecessary and irritating. There's no way to skip them or make them faster. You WILL "enjoy" them to the fullest EVERY TIME. It seems benign at the beginning, but a game like this should run instantly. This is the only way to facilitate players getting into the "zone" of repeating the gameplay loop until they sh√≠t themselves on stream. Instead, you spend about 3% of the game time actually thinking or clicking and 97% of the time just watching the same 5 animations which aren't even that entertaining in the first place. The whole interface is garbage. You can't even back out of using the shotgun or an item if you misclick, which is something that seems absolutely basic, expected, low bar and immediately detectable in any serious testing. But "nooo, this is le edgy game, no hand holding!!! You clicked the shotgun, so either choose the target or reset."

For some bizarre reason the online mode is for 4 players only, so I have no idea how that changes anything about the game, as no 9ne seems to play it online anymore.

This could have been a mildly entertaining VR experience, given some polish, QoL improvements and INSTANT game world feedback, but apparently this is too much to ask.

Buckshot Roulette is a gritty and dark depiction of a 1-on-1 showdown against a body-less nightmare in Russian Roulette. The twist? You play with a shotgun. The premise is creative, mayhaps even enticing, but the execution? Meh.

The game opens in a bathroom, graffiti'd and ominous. You're sat against a toothy demon of sorts and told to play his game. 30 minutes later, win or lose, credits roll, and you're out. What is this place? Who is this guy? Why am I here? Answer none of these questions and more in Buckshot Roulette!

The gameplay is simple, but satisfying to master. A number of rounds are loaded into the shotgun per round and you're shown how many are lives versus blanks. You must mentally keep track of this number while using items granted each round to eject the round, check the casing, and other effects. By the end of my duel with the Dealer, I felt I had achieved some sort of mastery, but unfortunately, this also spelled the end of the game, and that skill went to waste.

I think this game could've benefited a lot from a little exposition maybe, a few more challengers perhaps, another couple of items and combos to use... I'm told that's basically Inscryption, but this isn't Inscryption. It's Buckshot Roulette, and while it's cool on a conceptual level, it feels unfinished and closer to a stylish demo.

Review as a single player game:
At it's core, this is a puzzle game.  It is a puzzle game with a very grim aesthetic, but it's still just a puzzle game.

It's a very slight experience.  Which for just $3 is fine.  There is only one opponent in single player, and it is well coded to play mostly optimally.

And that's the main problem with the single player experience.  The items and mechanics are completely imbalanced to the randomization.  It is completely possible for the randomizer to give you a situation where even with perfect play it is impossible to win.  When you need to win roughly 15 straight games (for the million point achievements), that creates some VERY frustrating experiences.

This review is a victim of Steam's binary Yes/No review system.  It's an entertaining experience, but horribly broken.  Which is a shame, because with a little more work (better balancing on the items, a couple more opponents, a little more clarity on the scoring) this could have been a premium game.
Doesn't save any progress, not gonna go through all 3 levels again just because I wanted to turn down the super loud music.

Well, this game is neither fun nor well designed.

First off, this is pure luck (beside the stats that you can calculate). OK, to be fair, they added several objects to tamper the luck aspect of the game, but still. While in other roguelikes, the rng is not the sole aspect of the game, in Buckshot Roulette, there is nothing else to play with.

In the making, this game is also a chore: there is no way to pass all these lengthy animations (several seconds), which makes the game extremely slow pace, and thus artificially increasing the game play time, which I really hate.

Honestly, you will have more fun with a dice or two.
had fun for 2 - 3 runs but then it started getting repetitive, 100%ing is mid, just boring, it needs more settings and ai upgrade, for the price its a solid 6/10
boring and all luck no skill, I'm a big fan of gambling games but this is just so luck reliant it's also so boring I just can't have any fun. 2/10

I hate to give a negative review to a game I got in a bundle for practically nothing, but I'm honestly very confused as to how this game is rated overwhelmingly positive. 

The art style is okay, but that's the best thing about it, from what I've seen.

About 45 minutes in, and I feel like I've seen most of what this title has to offer. I haven't played all the way through the "Double or Nothing" mode, so possibly there's a lot I'm missing ... but from all appearances, I doubt it.

The core game loop is very simple, heavily RNG-based (not necessarily a bad thing), though there is some strategy available with usable items. In the time I've played, however, it feels pretty shallow.

I don't hate it, but it's pretty lackluster so far. Might give it another try and update this review if my opinion changes.

I did not make it through the first round of 3 games, including a second try at the second stage. You died. Retry? Absolutely not.

I can see in the screenshots it gets more complicated later, but I would rather saw my own arms off than endure sitting through all those long animations again

edit: I went back. I do not particularly enjoy games of chance, but you know what I should be fair - maybe this is just a 'not for me'. I'll check that there is not in fact a hurry the f$&% up mode in the settings. No? OK, maybe you can press a button or something, I can't remember for sure if I did that. After clicking start and waiting (pressing every key and button in the meantime) 3 seconds just for it to fade to black - before the game will even start - alt+f4 and I'm back here updating this text. I *hate* this game, and it's lack of respect for player's time.
Honestly, it's a really boring game and rather shallow. I would have said it's a waste of money - but it's ridiculously cheap to even say so.

The game is very fun, but it has unfortunately not recieved updates since 2024 and since the Vulkan driver updates, the game just doesn't load properly. You can use a workaround, but it doesn't seem to work for everyone and it's obviously not the way the game was intended to be rendered on screen. This seems to be more of an issue with the game engine than with the game itself, but still, I do not recommend buying this game until it is fixed.
